newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatian stocks close higher, further gains seen.
newsitem.headline: Croatian stocks close higher, further gains seen.

text.p: Most Croatian stocks resumed growth on Wednesday after Tuesday's public holiday, with blue chips breaking records in heavy trade.
Traders predicted further gains on the back of strong investor interest which comes in spite of the traditionally quieter holiday season.
"The growth trend should last at least until the end of this week," said one trader with a large foreign client base.
Drugs firm Pliva, selling 5,699 shares, was the most active issue. It firmed 18 kuna to close at a new all-time high of 584.
Zagrebacka Banka climbed 150 kuna to 2,500 -- also a record -- with 4,016 a total of units sold.

"Pliva and Zagrebacka did just great today. They led the whole market up and jointly accounted for almost the entire turnover," said Danijel Nevidal of CAIB, Austria's Credianstalt investment bank unit in Croatia.
He traced the developments to a rise in both blue chips' Global Depositary Receipts (GDRs) earlier today, saying growth in Zagreb could go on if the upward trend in London continues.
Zagrebacka's, issued at 10 of each share, rose to a record $38.125 on Seaq International with a spread of 1.57 percent over the Zagreb price.
Pliva's 1/5 GDRs fetched $17.6, compared to $17.5 at close on Tuesday.
Apart from these two, seven other of 18 active issues also rose in Zagreb on Wednesday, four fell and five ended flat.
Volume rose to 25,230 from last Friday's 9,898 shares, turnover was almost four times higher at 18.6 million kuna after trade quickened just before close at 1200 GMT.
The bourse was closed for Thanksgiving on Tuesday.
Varazdinska Banka ordinary shares rose 11 kuna to 250 on volume of 5,471. Its B-series preferred stock led gainers, adding 20 kuna or 13.3 percent to close at 170 kuna.
Food processor Podravka continued its recovery to close four kuna higher at 269 kuna with 5,479 shares sold.
"Podravka is quite liquid but we don't expect to see it rise much above 270 kuna, maybe a kuna or two," Nevidal said.
He said there was room for further growth of hotelier Laguna, which climbed 18 kuna to 1,468 with 576 shares sold.
The biggest loser was ship repairer Viktor Lenac which shed 10 kuna or 6.25 percent to 150 kuna, selling 270 units.
